awd_titl_txt: Materials World Network: Static and Dynamic Properties of Curved Multilayer Nanomagnets on Self-Assembled Particles
awd_abstract_narration:
Nanomagnets have a wide range of potential applications, including next generation high-density magnetic data storage, spintronic devices, and magnetic biosensing. Essential for all applications is an understanding of the underlying material properties and the capability to design and optimize these properties for the purpose at hand. In this collaborative effort between UC Santa Cruz and the Magnetic Nanostructures group of Manfred Albrecht (Chemnitz University of Technology, Germany), patterned nanomagnetic materials are fabricated and characterized to obtain a complete understanding of the material properties of curved metallic multilayer nanomagnets (?nanocaps?) for use in high-speed, high density magnetic data storage. Different metallic multilayer compositions are investigated and compared to more conventional flat nanomagnets. A complete picture of the dynamic properties of the magnetic nanocaps is obtained using time-resolved magneto-optical studies of single, isolated magnets and nanomagnets within an array. This comprehensive comparison results in a quantitative understanding of the influence of the magnetic environment on the dynamics of a single nanomagnet.

Broader impact of this research results from the straightforward application of the results of this project to other growing areas of nanomagnetic research such as magnetic memory, spintronics, or biosensors. In addition, joint educational activities between the participating groups take full advantage of the international nature of the collaboration. These include mutual, extended visits of students at different levels to the partner laboratory to gain experience in the complementary expertise of their colleagues. This experience improves the students? understanding of different cultures, research environments, and languages, and gives them a competitive edge in this highly international field.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Nanomagnets have a wide range of potential applications, including next generation high-density magnetic data storage, spintronic devices, and magnetic biosensing. Essential for all applications is an understanding of the underlying material properties and the capability to design and optimize these properties for the purpose at hand. In this collaborative effort between UC Santa Cruz and the Magnetic Nanostructures group of Manfred Albrecht (Chemnitz University of Technology, Germany), patterned nanomagnetic materials were fabricated and characterized to obtain a complete understanding of the material properties of curved metallic multilayer nanomagnets ("nanocaps") for use in high-speed, high density magnetic data storage. Different metallic material compositions were investigated and compared to more conventional flat nanomagnets. A complete picture of the dynamic properties of the magnetic nanocaps was obtained using time-resolved magneto-optical studies of single, isolated magnets and nanomagnets within an array. This comprehensive comparison resulted in a quantitative understanding of the influence of the magnetic environment on the dynamics of a single nanomagnet. Specifically, we investigated a number of material systems, including FePt, Fe, FexPt1-x, and CoCrPt. Through our extensive studies on magnetic materials with varying composition and three-dimensional shapes. we have gained an excellent qualitative and quantitative understanding of the dependence of magnetization dynamics on these parameters. In particular, our extensive studies on single nanocaps – the first of their kind - showed that three-dimensional shaping of nanomagnets provides a powerful option for tailoring the dynamic response due to the creation of intricate demagnetization field patterns.

Broader impact of this research results from the straightforward application of the results of this project to other growing areas of nanomagnetic research such as magnetic memory, spintronics, or biosensors. In addition, joint educational activities between the participating groups took full advantage of the international nature of the collaboration. These included mutual, extended visits of students to the partner laboratory to gain experience in the complementary expertise of their colleagues. In addition, industry guest lectures, both in Germany and the US, as well as outreach lectures and labs for summer high school students were conducted to increase awareness of cutting-edge research in nanomagnetism and magnetic materials.


Last Modified: 11/21/2012
Modified by: Holger Schmidt
por.por_txt_cntn:
Nanomagnets have a wide range of potential applications, including next  generation high-density magnetic data storage, spintronic devices, and  magnetic biosensing. Essential for all applications is an understanding  of the underlying material properties and the capability to design and  optimize these properties for the purpose at hand. In this collaborative  effort between UC Santa Cruz and the Magnetic Nanostructures group of  Manfred Albrecht (Chemnitz University of Technology, Germany), patterned  nanomagnetic materials were fabricated and characterized to obtain a  complete understanding of the material properties of curved metallic  multilayer nanomagnets ("nanocaps") for use in high-speed, high density  magnetic data storage. Different metallic material compositions were  investigated and compared to more conventional flat nanomagnets. A  complete picture of the dynamic properties of the magnetic nanocaps was  obtained using time-resolved magneto-optical studies of single, isolated  magnets and nanomagnets within an array. This comprehensive comparison  resulted in a quantitative understanding of the influence of the magnetic  environment on the dynamics of a single nanomagnet. Specifically, we investigated a number of material systems, including FePt, Fe, FexPt1-x, and CoCrPt. Through our extensive studies on magnetic materials with varying composition and three-dimensional shapes. we have gained an excellent qualitative and quantitative understanding of the dependence of magnetization dynamics on these parameters. In particular, our extensive studies on single nanocaps – the first of their kind - showed that three-dimensional shaping of nanomagnets provides a powerful option for tailoring the dynamic response due to the creation of intricate demagnetization field patterns.

Broader  impact of this research results from the straightforward application of  the results of this project to other growing areas of nanomagnetic  research such as magnetic memory, spintronics, or biosensors. In  addition, joint educational activities between the participating groups  took full advantage of the international nature of the collaboration.  These included mutual, extended visits of students to  the partner laboratory to gain experience in the complementary  expertise of their colleagues. In addition, industry guest lectures, both in Germany and the US, as well as outreach lectures and labs for summer high school students were conducted to increase awareness of cutting-edge research in nanomagnetism and magnetic materials.
